docs.lead_paragraph: The states hope to be among the big winners if Congress passes a Medicare drug benefit, allowing them to shift expenses from state-financed programs onto the new federal program. The windfall could be billions of dollars a year, or it could be far less, depending on how differences between the Senate and House versions of the Medicare bill are hashed out in a conference committee. Even if a program won approval, experts caution, it would be so complex, and so far in the future -- it would begin to go into effect in 2006, with some pieces coming much later -- that the effect on the states would not be fully comprehended for years.

headline.main: States May Benefit, as Well, If Medicare Drug Bill Passes

docs.abstract: States hope to be big winners if Congress passes Medicare drug benefit allowing them to shift expenses from their own programs onto new federal program; savings could reach billions of dollars a year, depending on how differences between House and Senate versions of bill are settled in conference committee; New York could be biggest beneficiary because it spends more than any another state on health care programs, including $3 billion on drug coverage (M)
docs.snippet: The states hope to be among the big winners if Congress passes a Medicare drug benefit, allowing them to shift expenses from state-financed programs onto the new federal program.    The windfall could be billions of dollars a year, or it could be far...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''H'' stands for ''high'' -- that's how to remember which of your cholesterol readings should be as high as you can get it: H.D.L.-C. Known as the good cholesterol, it is the common designation for high-density lipoprotein cholesterol. It is the cholesterol-carrying protein in your blood that acts like arterial Drano, helping to keep critical blood vessels from clogging up with circulation-impeding deposits.

headline.main: Cholesterol: When It's Good, It's Very, Very Good

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses importance of having good cholesterol and how to get it; Dr Michael Miller, University of Maryland Medical Center for Preventive Cardiology director, explains that low levels of good cholesterol are considered stronger indicator of coronary heart disease than high levels of bad cholesterol; diet, exercise and moderate use of alcohol have all been shown to effect good cholesterol; several heart-protective and good cholesterol-raising drugs are mentioned; cartoon (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Leaders of the nation's most prominent black civil rights organization attacked three Democratic presidential candidates today for failing to show up for a forum that the group held here at its annual convention. The six Democratic presidential contenders who did attend the forum by the N.A.A.C.P. appeared on a stage alongside empty chairs with placards bearing the names of the three who did not attend: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Representative Dennis J. Kucinich of Ohio.

headline.main: No-Show Equals No Vote, Irate N.A.A.C.P. Hosts Say

docs.abstract: NAACP leaders attack Democratic presidential aspirants Joseph Lieberman, Richard Gephardt and Dennis Kucinich for not appearing at annual convention in Miami Beach; six other contenders appear on stage with empty chairs, including one for Pres Bush; president Kweisi Mfume says three are 'persona non grata'; photo; three issue statements saying no offense was intended (M)

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: NATIONAL ASSN FOR THE ADVANCEMENT OF COLORED PEOPLE

docs.lead_paragraph: The Big Three automakers, which open contract talks with the United Auto Workers union on Wednesday, are making a bigger issue out of reducing medical costs than they have in years. But the union has staked out health insurance as untouchable. ''We're not going to share costs,'' said Ron Gettelfinger, the U.A.W. president, at a recent news briefing.

headline.main: Their Health Costs Soaring, Automakers Are to Begin Labor Talks

docs.abstract: Big Three automakers, which open contract talks with United Auto Workers union on July 16, are making bigger issue out of reducing medical costs than they have in years; UAW president Ron Gettelfinger says health insurance issue is untouchable; auto industry experts believe union may give ground on issues like wage increases, plant closings or work rules; graph (M)
docs.snippet: The Big Three automakers, which open contract talks with the United Auto Workers union on Wednesday, are making a bigger issue out of reducing medical costs than they have in years.    But the union has staked out health insurance as untouchable....

docs.lead_paragraph: Sometimes medicines prescribed for one disorder will help patients with a different one. In today's issue of The Annals of Internal Medicine, two studies followed up on such promising signs; one found them to be borne out, while the other did not. One looked at the effect of a class of blood pressure drugs called ACE inhibitors on people with diabetes.
docs.abstract: Dutch researchers study, published in Annals of Internal Medicine, finds that ACE inhibitors, typically prescribed for high blood pressure, resulted in significant reductions in kidney damaging albumin when given to patients with diabetes; alleged connection between statins, used primarily to treat high cholesterol, and prevention or control of osteoporosis is dispelled by evidence collected in database of Women's Health Initiative observational study and also published in Annals of Internal Medicine; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Sometimes medicines prescribed for one disorder will help patients with a different one. In today's issue of The Annals of Internal Medicine, two studies followed up on such promising signs; one found them to be borne out, while the other did not.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: No branch of medicine intersects with politics more than public health. Not surprisingly, the two areas often clash, particularly when health issues bear on economics, like SARS and tobacco use. Few know this interplay better than Dr. Gro Harlem Brundtland, a physician and Harvard-trained public health specialist, who next week ends her five-year term as director general of the World Health Organization here.

headline.main: An Era Ends, Many Missions Accomplished

docs.abstract: World Health Organization's director general Dr Gro Harlem Brundtland leaves office next week after one five-year term; faced with emergence of SARS and fueled by her determination to eradicate polio, make drugs accessible to poor and control worldwide use of tobacco, Brundtland acknowledges organization is in better place to effect change than when she began in 1998; her background is given and some success stories discussed, including Framework Convention on Tobacco Control; effective handling of SARS epidemic by WHO, under leadership of Brundtland, is credited with sparking renewed collaborative efforts between nations to proactively fight disease; Dr Jong Wook Lee will be her successor as director general; photo (M)
